Award.AwardTitle: Scientists as Teachers; Teachers as Scientists

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists as Teachers ? Teachers as Scientists

This project addresses two significant issues; the need to improve graduate students education and training for careers either in or outside the laboratory, and for the educational and research communities to collaborate at all levels of the educational spectrum to improve K12 science achievement.

The goals of the project include: Improved communication, collaboration, team building and leadership (graduate fellows); improved outreach and collaborations (STEM faculty); increased professional development and research laboratory skills (high school teachers); increased science achievement and interest in STEM careers (high school students); improved graduate education (Temple University). Key elements of this project are: (1) a required science ethics course for all Fellows; (2) a professional development program that STEM faculty and teaching and learning experts will pilot with the intent to incorporate into a college-wide permanent addition to the graduate programs; (3) the GK Fellows in-school component, and (4) GK Fellows /teacher summer institute which will combine pedagogy, content, and laboratory research.

The broader impact of the project includes the immediate affect all participants by improving STEM graduate education at Temple University and increasing collaborative relationships between a large urban university and the complex urban school district of Philadelphia. On-line and in-person dissemination of the outcomes will support the wider impact of the project. Changes in the graduate science programs will have lasting effects on the participants and future Temple University students throughout their careers and students at other universities implementing elements of our project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists as Teachers – Teaches as Scientists, Temple University, Philadelphia, PA

The National Science Foundation (NSF) program funding this project focused on improving graduate science students’ communication skills, especially communicating science to widely varied audiences. Within this context this project was designed to improve teaching and learning of science in both university and pre-college settings and addresses two significant issues: 1) the need to better prepare graduate students for the world both in and beyond the laboratory as their careers may take many different paths and 2) the need for the educational and research communities to interact at all levels of the educational spectrum. The specific focus on graduate students was especially important as they are a key component in this process as they are the future of science.

 In the project, professional development programming was provided to the graduate fellows to improve their communication and presentation skills. An ethics course was required to deepen their appreciation of role science plays in society. Indirect mentoring of the fellows was provided by the participating School District of Philadelphia high school science teachers they were paired with. They, the fellows, in turn, were expected to bring their research into these classrooms and function as role models and mentors to the high school students. To determine the effect of the graduate students’ presence, student course grades were analyzed in terms of student characteristics and attitudes, and graduate student time in the classroom and other characteristics.

 Over the course of the six years of this project, 27 graduate students spread across 7 STEM disciplines participated. In addition, 23 high school science teachers from 7 School District of Philadelphia schools intensively participated. Additional teachers in those schools benefitted through interactions with the participating teachers. In each year more than 1,000 students were affected. Analyses of the data collected demonstrated two findings. First, there was a letter grade difference between students in the GF classrooms and those in control classrooms. Secondly, the “optimal” number of hours of GF mentoring in the high school classroom, measured in terms of the students’ grades, was captured at 4.8 hours per week.

 In Year 6 of the project, two of the participating graduate students were asked to “apply what they had learned” after working with the high school students and their teachers for a year. Over the course of this second year of participation they were to build on the contacts made during the university provided professional development programs they participated in and develop and implement presentations or workshops of their own. In all the two graduate fellows participating in this component of the project, made over 10 presentations, served as mentors for 8 programs, and developed and implemented a community outreach program of STEM volunteering opportunities. The wide variety of topics reached over 200 students in person and countless others online.  Among the topics were: How do I display research experience on my resume?; Undergraduate research opportunities; Email etiquette; So you want undergraduate research?; Federal post graduate fellowship opportunities; Research ethics; Resource Kit: Keeping a field notebook; Resource Kit: Human drug testing; Resource Kit: Predator prey interactions in marine habitats; Resource Kit: Evolution of cryptic coloration; Resources for success at Temple University.
